record.field: Nil per Os. Withhold oral food and fluids from the patient
Easily digested, semi-liquid foods to be consumed in small amounts.
Soft or pureed foods that are easy to chew and digest
Soft foods such as cooked vegetables and soft or ground meats
This diet is frequently used for GYN surgical patients. Provides foods such as non-cream based soups, Jell-O, juice, lactaid milk, tea and coffee
Soft bland foods that have low fiber content. Lactose is limited.
Low sugar, low fat, low lactose foods. No fluids with meals. Small frequent feedings
For patients who have difficulty in chewing or swallowing
For patients with problems chewing and swallowing or esophageal inflammation or varices. Food consistency is blended. Liquids must be ordered separately as regular, nectar, or honey.

Mechanically altered. Meats are ground or minced. Foods are moist, soft-textured, and easily formed into a bolus. All vegetables are fork-mashable. Liquids must be ordered separately as regular, nectar, or honey.

Foods are nearly regular textures with the exception of hard, sticky, or crunchy foods. Foods are moist, bite-sized pieces. All vegetables are fork-mashable. Liquids must be ordered separately as regular, nectar, or honey.
Provides controlled amounts of sodium, cholesterol, saturated and total fat
Provides less than 30% energy from fat.
4 grams Sodium. Provides a moderate sodium restriction by eliminating foods and condiments high in sodium
Used in the treatment of conditions characterized by edema, including the following: cirrhosis of the liver with ascites, Congested Heart Failure - CHF, essential hypertension and renal disease.
Provides adequate protein (80 - 100g/d) and limited amounts of potassium (2g) and sodium (2g) for the dialyzed patient.
Provides limited amounts of protein (40-60g/d), potassium (2g/d), and sodium (2g/d) for the pre-dialyzed patient.
The diet limits most raw, highly-seasoned and fried foods. The diet contains only moderate amounts of fiber
The diet eliminates seasoned foods and condiments that may stimulate gastric discomfort and GERD

1200-3000 cal/day .The diet provides consistent amount of carbohydrate based on caloric level to allow for optimal blood glucose control. The diet provides a Bedtime snack for all calorie levels. (45% CHO, 25% protein, 30% fat)

1800-3000 cal/day .The diet provides consistent amount of carbohydrate based on caloric level to allow for optimal blood glucose control. Snacks provided between meals to provide approximately 35-40% of Kcal from CHO.

The diet provides bland, room temperature or cold foods separated into solids and liquids. Patients on this diet may request additional foods they feel can be tolerated. Patients are encouraged to separate their intake of food and drink
The diet provides 6 small meals daily

The diet is indicated for short-term use whenever an acute illness or surgery causes intolerance to food; or to temporarily restrict undigested material in the GI tract. The diet is not nutritionally adequate.
Clear liquid diet providing sugar-free products only (No Concentrated Sugar). This diet provides very limited amounts of carbohydrate.
The diet consists of foods that are liquid at body temperature. Foods are easy to digest and provide minimal stimulation to the GI tract. The diet is not nutritionally adequate.
The diet eliminates certain foods to provide a lower level of bacteria than is present in a typical hospital diet.
The diet omits foods processed with Gluten. The diet is the primary means of treatment for celiac sprue
Indicated for patients who may not be able to use utensils or for patients confined to a flat-lying position who require heart healthy foods.
